event.name: RENT
event.description: Jonathan Larson’s beloved Pulitzer Prize–winning cult classic returns to the stage this summer. In homage to RENT’s original production, this revival will feature the original director as well as a cast compiled entirely of undiscovered talent found at open auditions. Relive the story that defined a generation and gave a voice to a minority that demanded and deserved recognition. Don’t miss this important piece of Broadway history! For more information, visit siteforrent.com.

event.name: Jazz at Lincoln Center 2011â€“2012 Season
event.description: Jazz at Lincoln Center has expanded its horizons and upped the ante like never before for its landmark 25th season. With this year’s lineup of performers and honorees, artistic director Wynton Marsalis again has shown his dedication to honoring the history of this unique American art form while also keeping an eye to its present and future. Among the many scheduled highlights: Opening Night with Jimmy Heath and Jon Hendricks (September 24), Impulse Records’ 50th Anniversary Celebration (October 28–29), Astor Piazzolla (November 11–12), Dianne Reeves (February 24–25), Herbie Hancock (March 9–10) and a new focus on the blues with the legendary Taj Mahal & the Phantom Blues Band (April 19–20). For more information, visit jalc.org.

event.name: War Horse
event.description: Though it's based on Michael Morpurgo's children's novel War Horse, this new play isn't just for kids. The haunting, heartrending drama revolves around Joey, a horse that's sold to the British army during World War I and then reunited with his former owner in battle. Directors Marianne Elliott and Tom Morris were responsible for the original production, which picked up a few Olivier Awards in 2008 and is still running on the West End. They'll be working with a cast of 35—of whom a dozen will be playing life-size skeletal horses crafted by the Handspring Puppet Company.

event.name: Sister Act
event.description: Praise the Lord, Sister Act: A Divine Musical Comedy is finally coming to Broadway. It became the talk of the town in London, where it premiered on the West End in 2009. Unfortunately, Whoopi Goldberg is too busy trading banter on The View to reprise her role as Sister Mary Clarence, the showgirl-turned-nun she played in the 1992 film, but she remains on the marquee as a producer. Spunky, big-voiced Patina Miller is a worthy replacement, though, leading the chorus of nuns, decked out in ready-for-the-stage sparkly habits and singing original songs like "Raise Your Voice" and "Take Me to Heaven" by Alan Menken of Disney fame (The Little Mermaid, Aladdin). This show is participating in Broadway Week. For information on purchasing 2-for-1 tickets (good for performances September 18–30), visit nycgo.com/broadwayweek.

event.name: Anything Goes
event.description: Sutton Foster has some big tap shoes to fill as she takes on the role of Reno Sweeney, a nightclub singer on an ocean liner, in this Cole Porter classic. The legendary Ethel Merman originated the role in 1934, and Patti LuPone followed in the 1987 revival. But Foster, having starred in Thoroughly Modern Millie and The Drowsy Chaperone, is no stranger to the spotlight, and director-choreographer Kathleen Marshall, who won a Tony for The Pajama Game, is hewing close to the flashy original (with songs like "I Get a Kick Out of You," "All Through the Night" and "You're the Top," can you blame her?). As if that isn't exhilarating enough, relative newcomer Colin Donnell, who plays one of the young lovers, is the stuff Broadway heartthrobs are made of. For more information, visit roundabouttheatre.org.

event.name: Priscilla Queen of the Desert
event.description: The Divine Miss M signed on to produce this new musical based on the 1994 cult-favorite film of the same name about—what else?—divas. Two drag queens and a transsexual travel across the Australian desert on a broken-down bus, stopping every now and then to kick up their heels to more than 20 chart toppers from the '60s, '70s and '80s, including "I Will Survive," "It's Raining Men" and "I Say a Little Prayer." Priscilla also marks the first time a Madonna song will be performed on Broadway. We hear Nick Adams (as the fierce Felicia) serves up a rousing rendition of "Like a Prayer" that's sure to make Madge proud. This show is participating in Broadway Week. For information on purchasing 2-for-1 tickets (good for performances September 18–30), visit nycgo.com/broadwayweek.

event.name: How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying
event.description:
See Harry Potter star Daniel Radcliffe (Equus on Broadway) and Tony Award winner John Larroquette (Night Court, The Practice) live on Broadway in the blockbuster musical comedy hit, How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying. Enjoy a riotous rise up the corporate ladder in this new production that the Daily News says is "sleek and sophisticated, packed with stunning visuals!" So make your way to the top and get your tickets to what the Chicago Tribune calls "great fun for everybody!"

 Sponsored by How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying

event.name: Catch Me if You Can
event.description:
Based on the Academy Award–nominated movie by the same title, Catch Me If You Can comes to Broadway as a musical featuring an all-star cast worthy of taking on this ambitious project. Aaron Tveit (Next to Normal) plays Frank Abagnale, Jr., an adventurous teenager with a talent for check-forging, who travels the world under the guise of several identities. Kerry Butler (Hairspray) plays Frank's love interest; Norbert Leo Butz (Dirty Rotten Scoundrels) plays Car Hanratty, the FBI agent in pursuit of Frank Jr.; and Tom Wopat (Annie Get Your Gun) plays Frank Sr., who lives out his dreams through his son.

The Broadway Accessibility Initiative, the result of a partnership between organizations Alliance for Inclusion in the Arts and G-PASS, offers theatergoers with disabilities the opportunity to enjoy more Broadway shows. Currently featured in Catch Me If You Can, the program's services include I-Caption for deaf and hard-of-hearing patrons, D-Scriptive for blind and low-vision theatre-goers and ShowTrans for non-English-speaking audience members. All are available free of charge at every performance. For more information, visit inclusioninthearts.org.

event.name: Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark
event.description: If your spidey sense is tingling, it's probably because the most-talked-about new show of the year has made its way to Broadway. Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark has all the makings of a monster hit, with original music by U2's Bono and The Edge. The big-budget rock musical is one of the most technically complex shows ever to run on Broadway and features many awe-inspiring stunts, such as aerial combat scenes and a multitude of moving pieces that put the audience at the center of the action.

image.alt: Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark - TEMPORARILY CLOSED
image.title: Photo: Jacob Cohl

image.alt: Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark - TEMPORARILY CLOSED

image.alt: Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark - TEMPORARILY CLOSED
image.title: NULL

event.name: The Addams Family
event.description: This long-awaited production stars Roger Rees and Brooke Shields as Gomez and Morticia Addams, heads of the famously ghoulish clan. Though not short on theatrics, the production draws its inspiration more from the original New Yorker cartoons by Charles Addams, with their pitch-black humor, rather than the TV show and movies that followed. Marshall Brickman and Rick Elice, authors of Jersey Boys, created this new twist on an old classic. This show is participating in Broadway Week. For information on purchasing 2-for-1 tickets (good for performances September 18–30), visit nycgo.com/broadwayweek.

event.name: Memphis
event.description: This electrifying musical about the early days of rock 'n' roll, loosely based on a true story, follows a talented black female singer who can't break out of the segregated club circuit and a white radio DJ who introduces his listeners to the first recorded rock 'n' roll. When they come together, they find love and usher in the golden age of rock—but realize that the world might not be ready for them. This show is participating in Broadway Week. For information on purchasing 2-for-1 tickets (good for performances September 18–30), visit nycgo.com/broadwayweek.

event.name: Rock of Ages
event.description: The hair-metal bands of the '80s have inspired this theatrical experience, a period piece set in the Hollywood of two decades ago. Rock of Ages features big chords, big dreams and big hair! This show is participating in Broadway Week. For information on purchasing 2-for-1 tickets (good for performances September 18–30), visit nycgo.com/broadwayweek.

address.address_1: 240 W. 44th St. (bet. Eighth Ave. and Shubert Alley)

event.name: Wicked
event.description: Winner of 35 major awards, including the Grammy Award and three Tony Awards, Wicked is the untold story of the witches of Oz. Long before Dorothy drops in, two other girls meet in the Land of Oz. One, born with emerald-green skin, is smart, fiery and misunderstood. The other is beautiful, ambitious and very popular. Wicked tells the story of their remarkable odyssey—how these two unlikely friends grow to become the Wicked Witch of the West and Glinda the Good. Based on the novel by Gregory Maguire, Wicked has music and lyrics by Stephen Schwartz (Godspell, Pippin Enchanted), and a book by Winnie Holzman (My So-Called Life, thirtysomething, Huge). The production is directed by Tony Award winner Joe Mantello (Assassins, Other Desert Cities, Three Days of Rain) with musical staging by Wayne Cilento (The Who’s Tommy, Aida). This show is participating in Broadway Week. For information on purchasing 2-for-1 tickets (good for performances September 18–30), visit nycgo.com/broadwayweek.

event.name: The Phantom of the Opera
event.description: Andrew Lloyd Webber’s most famous creation, based on a popular French novel, is the longest-running musical on Broadway. Night after night, audiences are moved and awed by this ghost story with a heart, a darker version of Beauty and the Beast, in which a deformed musical genius gives voice lessons to a struggling singer, falls in love and attempts to force her to return his feelings. The passionate music, suspenseful plot twists and spooky ambiance of the show leave a lasting impression. This show is participating in Broadway Week. For information on purchasing 2-for-1 tickets (good for performances September 18–30), visit nycgo.com/broadwayweek.

event.name: Jersey Boys
event.description: Jersey Boys tells the story of Frankie Valli and the Four Seasons: Frankie Valli, Bob Gaudio, Tommy DeVito and Nick Massi. The musical chronicles these blue-collar boys from the wrong side of the tracks on their journey to pop stardom. Dark Monday. This show is participating in Broadway Week. For information on purchasing 2-for-1 tickets (good for performances September 18–30), visit nycgo.com/broadwayweek.

event.name: Chicago
event.description: This quintessential Broadway experience features show-stopping tunes, slinky dancing and a story that revolves around murder, heartache, betrayal, revenge, friendship, fame and all that jazz. You won’t be disappointed by this Tony Award-winning show, which spawned the hit movie. Dark Wednesday. This show is participating in Broadway Week. For information on purchasing 2-for-1 tickets (good for performances September 18–30), visit nycgo.com/broadwayweek.

event.name: Billy Elliot the Musical
event.description: Billy Elliot arrived on Broadway from the West End, where it nabbed four Laurence Olivier Awards (British theater's most prestigious accolade). With music by Elton John, the show is based on the popular 2000 film of the same name and was created by the film's director, Stephen Daldry. The heartwarming story explores a young British boy's love for dance in a world where boys don't dance—they box. The performances from the cast—including an ensemble of gifted youngsters—will leave you wanting more after they take their final bow. If you're still not convinced, keep in mind that at 15, the musical scored more 2009 Tony Award nominations than any other Broadway act, tying The Producers for the most nods ever received by a single show. That's 15 more reasons to go see what all the fuss is about. For more information, visit billyelliotbroadway.com.This show is participating in Broadway Week. For information on purchasing 2-for-1 tickets (good for performances September 18–30), visit nycgo.com/broadwayweek.

event.name: Mamma Mia!
event.description: Even if you’re not an ABBA fanatic, there’s no resisting the charm of this upbeat hit musical about a Greek island wedding and a young bride’s quest to connect with her biological father, who could be one of three different, wonderful men who once loved her free-spirited mother, who runs a beachside taverna. If you’re not dancing in the aisle—or at least tapping your feet—by the end of the night, have your doctor check your vital signs. Dark Monday and Tuesday. This show is participating in Broadway Week. For information on purchasing 2-for-1 tickets (good for performances September 18–30), visit nycgo.com/broadwayweek.

event.name: Mary Poppins
event.description: Now in its fifth phenomenal year at the New Amsterdam Theatre on 42nd Street, Mary Poppins has astonished over six million people with its own brand of Broadway magic. Featuring the irresistible story and unforgettable songs from one of the most popular Disney films of all time, plus brand-new breathtaking dance numbers and spectacular stage-craft, Mary Poppins is everything you could ever want in a hit Broadway show! So get swept up in the fun of this high-flying musical the New York Post gives 4 out of 4 stars and calls "a perfect piece of musical theater." This show is participating in Broadway Week. For information on purchasing 2-for-1 tickets (good for performances September 18–30), visit nycgo.com/broadwayweek.

event.name: The Lion King
event.description: More than 55 million people around the world have come to discover the thrill, the majesty, the truly one-of-a-kind musical that is The Lion King. And there's no better place to experience this landmark entertainment event than in the city where it all began. Join us at the Minskoff Theatre, in the heart of Times Square, and discover the pride of New York. This show is participating in Broadway Week. For information on purchasing 2-for-1 tickets (good for performances September 18–30), visit nycgo.com/broadwayweek.

event.name: Hair
event.description: After a successful run in the Public Theater's "Shakespeare in the Park" program followed by a Broadway run, Hair continues its rockin' revival. The show shares its message of peace, love and freedom at the St. James Theatre, where its bittersweet depiction of youth now resonates with a whole new generation—just as vibrantly as when it first premiered more than 40 years ago. Considering its multiple 2009 Tony Award nominations it's safe to say this musical's latest iteration will make audiences of all ages want to let their hair down. For more information visit hairontour.com

event.name: The Mountaintop
event.description: Samuel L. Jackson stars as Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. on the eve of his assassination in the Katori Hall's lavishly praised The Mountaintop. In this fictionalized tale, Dr. King meets a woman, played by Angela Bassett, following his "I've Been to the Mountaintop" speech, setting off a storm of pride and regret over his life and legacy. Jazz great Branford Marsalis contributes the original score. For more information, visit themountaintopplay.com. This show is participating in Broadway Week. For information on purchasing 2-for-1 tickets (good for performances September 18–30), visit nycgo.com/broadwayweek.

event.name: Man and Boy
event.description: Playwright Terence Rattigan's Man and Boy finds its cutthroat capitalist protagonist, Gregor Antonescu, reaching out to his estranged, socialist son in a time of need. But his motivations appear to be founded in greed, rather than affection. The brilliant acting of Frank Langella propels this production from Roundabout Theatre Company. For more information, visit roundabouttheatre.org. This show is participating in Broadway Week. For information on purchasing 2-for-1 tickets (good for performances September 18–30), visit nycgo.com/broadwayweek.

event.name: The Columnist
event.description: The titular columnist is one Joseph Alsop, a fascinating true-life journalist, power broker, conservative, J.F.K. advisor, homosexual and target of KGB smear tactics. The Columnist sees Alsop at the height of his influence, hosting his Kennedy coterie while trying to tamp down his personal secrets. The Columnist is the latest work from David Auburn, who won both a Pulitzer and a Tony for his 2001 play, Proof.

event.name: Relatively Speaking
event.description: It's indisputably certain that the star power of Relatively Speaking is just about unprecedented for a set of one-act plays. None other than Ethan Coen, Elaine May and Woody Allen each penned a comedy for this production, all directed by John Turturro and featuring a large veteran cast, including Marlo Thomas, Steve Guttenberg and Julie Kavner. Family dysfunction is the unifying thread for this unique theatrical event. For more information, visit relativelyspeakingbroadway.com. This show is participating in Broadway Week. For information on purchasing 2-for-1 tickets (good for performances September 18–30), visit nycgo.com/broadwayweek.

event.name: Godspell
event.description: Theatergoers everywhere have cherished Godspell since its 1970 debut. The story is based on the Gospel of Matthew, with music and lyrics from Stephen Schwartz (of Wicked fame). For this return to Broadway, Godspell's thoughtful re-imaginings of traditional parables prove as powerful and enduring as they were 40 years ago. For more information, visit godspell.com.

event.name: Bonnie & Clyde
event.description: The murderous, glamorous, real-life exploits of Bonnie Parker and Clyde Barrow have captivated the public since the 1930s. The musical Bonnie & Clyde may have only been captivating audiences since 2009, but we predict serious staying power, thanks to a killer cast and great songs, which mine rockabilly, blues and country. For more information, visit bonnieandclydebroadway.com.

event.name: Stick Fly
event.description: Stick Fly finds a well-heeled, middle-aged couple reunited with their two adult sons, and respective girlfriends, for a Martha's Vineyard weekend of mirth and a little madness. Race, class and generational identity are skewered with biting wit and broad humor. Grammy Award–winning musician Alicia Keys co-produces. For more information, visit stickflybroadway.com.

event.name: Porgy and Bess
event.description: Porgy and Bess, one of America's most lauded operas, has stunned audiences since its 1935 debut with its melding of jazz and folk into classical music, regional dialect and an unflinching—and controversial—depiction of poor southern African-American struggles with drugs and violence. This adaptation transfigures the George and Ira Gershwin classic and features the acting talents of David Alan Grier.

event.name: Private Lives
event.description: Noël Coward's 1930 comedy Private Lives finds a divorced couple rekindling their passion at the most surprising time—while honeymooning with new spouses. The playful, risqué work is beautifully cast, with Kim Cattrall and Paul Gross playing the once-again lovers on Broadway on the heels of a successful run in London. For more information, visit privatelivesbroadway.com.

event.name: Follies
event.description: Bernadette Peters and Jan Maxwell revive Stephen Sondheim’s majestic musical on Broadway this fall. Based on the Ziegfeld Follies of yore, we find a reunion of performers reliving the glory of their once-beloved show, as they reflect on all that has—and hasn’t—changed since their '30s heyday. For more information, visit folliesbroadway.com.

event.name: Other Desert Cities
event.description: Rachel Griffiths (Six Feet Under, Brother and Sisters) plays to her considerable strengths in the drama department with Other Desert Cities. Her protagonist returns to her childhood Palm Springs home with unwelcome news of her upcoming tell-all memoir, plunging her family reunion into painful recriminations. Stockard Channing is among the other actors in Other Desert Cities’ outstanding cast. For more information, visit lct.org.

event.name: On a Clear Day You Can See Forever
event.description: Rarely seen on stages since its 1965 debut, On a Clear Day You Can See Forever is transformed in this Broadway run, starring the inimitable Harry Connick, Jr. as a psychiatrist summoning a patient’s past life during therapy. Hilarity and poignancy ensue, as the good doctor falls for the alter ego in this time- and gender-bending love story. For more information, visit onacleardaybroadway.com.

image.title: Harry Connick, Jr. Photo: Palma Kolansky

event.name: Lysistrata Jones
event.description: Aristophanes' comedy of sexual politics gets a power-pop score, an updated setting and a home on Broadway in Lysistrata Jones. Decades of failure for Athens University’s basketball team might be at an end when the team’s girlfriends vow to keep their men begging for attention until they start scoring on the court. For more information, visit lysistratajones.com.
